articles.headline: Meta Accused by States of Using Features to Lure Children to Instagram and Facebook
articles.snippet: More than three dozen states and the District of Columbia accused the tech giant of knowingly using addictive features to draw in and retain children and teenagers.
articles.abstract: More than three dozen states and the District of Columbia accused the tech giant of knowingly using addictive features to draw in and retain children and teenagers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Meta was sued by more than three dozen states on Tuesday for knowingly using features on Instagram and Facebook to hook children to its platforms, even as the company said its social media sites were safe for young people.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and Natasha Singer

articles.headline: As Gaza Barrage and Deaths Surge, Angry Accusations Fly at U.N.
articles.snippet: Israel said it struck more than 400 targets in Gaza in its broadest single-day assault of the conflict. Palestinian officials said more than 700 were killed, the highest one-day toll of the war.
articles.abstract: Israel said it struck more than 400 targets in Gaza in its broadest single-day assault of the conflict. Palestinian officials said more than 700 were killed, the highest one-day toll of the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: Escalating its onslaught against Hamas, Israel hit the Gaza Strip with hundreds of airstrikes in a single day, Israeli officials said Tuesday, and officials in Hamas-controlled Gaza said it was the deadliest day for Palestinians there since the conflict began.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee, Farnaz Fassihi and Eric Nagourney

articles.headline: ‘I Went Through Hell,’ Freed Israeli, 85, Says of Subterranean Captivity in Gaza
articles.snippet: Yocheved Lifshitz, a grandmother and Israeli peace activist, was kidnapped, beaten and held in tunnels built by Hamas for 17 days.
articles.abstract: Yocheved Lifshitz, a grandmother and Israeli peace activist, was kidnapped, beaten and held in tunnels built by Hamas for 17 days.
articles.lead_paragraph: In harrowing detail, an 85-year-old Israeli grandmother described her 17-day ordeal as a hostage, offering for the first time a captive’s account of the armed Palestinian group Hamas’s subterranean garrison beneath Gaza, the conditions in which the group’s hostages are being held and the operatives deployed to tend to them.

articles.headline: A Close Look at Some Key Evidence in the Gaza Hospital Blast
articles.snippet: A widely cited missile video does not shed light on what happened, a Times analysis concludes.
articles.abstract: A widely cited missile video does not shed light on what happened, a Times analysis concludes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The video shows a projectile streaking through the darkened skies over Gaza and exploding in the air. Seconds later, another explosion is seen on the ground.
articles.byline: By Aric Toler, Haley Willis, Riley Mellen, Alexander Cardia, Natalie Reneau, Julian E. Barnes and Christoph Koettl

articles.headline: What the U.S. Has Argued in the Google Antitrust Trial
articles.snippet: As the government wraps up its case in the landmark monopoly trial, it has built a picture of how Google became dominant in online search — and the harms that it says resulted.
articles.abstract: As the government wraps up its case in the landmark monopoly trial, it has built a picture of how Google became dominant in online search — and the harms that it says resulted.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since Sept. 12., the Department of Justice and a group of state attorneys general have questioned more than 30 witnesses as they try to prove that Google broke antitrust laws, in a landmark monopoly trial that may affect the power of the technology industry.
articles.byline: By David McCabe, Cecilia Kang and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: For a Grandmother in Gaza, History Is Scarier Than Airstrikes
articles.snippet: From his Los Angeles home, Mohammed Abujayyab has sought to help his grandmother and other relatives survive the Israeli bombardment. Memories of displacement are never far.
articles.abstract: From his Los Angeles home, Mohammed Abujayyab has sought to help his grandmother and other relatives survive the Israeli bombardment. Memories of displacement are never far.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mohammed Abujayyab was at his wits’ end.

articles.headline: Thirst and Hunger Grow in Besieged Gaza Amid Israeli Bombardment
articles.snippet: Residents wait in line for hours for bread and water, with fights sometimes breaking out. The United Nations has called the situation a humanitarian catastrophe.
articles.abstract: Residents wait in line for hours for bread and water, with fights sometimes breaking out. The United Nations has called the situation a humanitarian catastrophe.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mohammed Aborjela, 27, used to document daily life in the Gaza Strip on his Instagram account before the war, videos about a crab dish prepared along the seaside or pigeon racing in the coastal enclave.
articles.byline: By Raja Abdulrahim and Samar Abu Elouf

articles.headline: Chasing Big Mergers, Oil Executives Dismiss Peak Oil Concerns
articles.snippet: Exxon Mobil and Chevron are spending tens of billions of dollars buying oil and gas assets, betting that the International Energy Agency’s predictions of declining oil demand are wrong.
articles.abstract: Exxon Mobil and Chevron are spending tens of billions of dollars buying oil and gas assets, betting that the International Energy Agency’s predictions of declining oil demand are wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the two largest U.S. oil companies, this month committed to spending more than $50 billion each to buy smaller companies in deals that would let them produce more oil and natural gas for decades to come.

articles.headline: House Elects Mike Johnson as Speaker, Embracing a Hard-Right Conservative
articles.snippet: Republicans turned to a little-known Louisiana lawmaker who led congressional efforts to overturn the 2020 election, ending a weekslong deadlock that paralyzed the House.
articles.abstract: Republicans turned to a little-known Louisiana lawmaker who led congressional efforts to overturn the 2020 election, ending a weekslong deadlock that paralyzed the House.
articles.lead_paragraph: Representative Mike Johnson of Louisiana won election on Wednesday to become the 56th speaker of the House of Representatives, as Republicans worn down by three weeks of infighting and dysfunction turned to a little-known conservative hard-liner beloved by the far right to end their paralysis.
